issue_type: Poor network coverage in rural areas
issue_description: The telecom network coverage is weak or non-existent in rural areas, causing difficulties in making or receiving calls, sending messages, or accessing mobile internet.

immediate_action: Contact your telecom operator’s customer care (Toll-Free 1800 series) or visit the nearest store.
Lodge a formal complaint and get a Complaint Reference Number.
Most telecom operators also offer online grievance forms via their websites or mobile apps.
if_unresolved: If not resolved within 7 working days, escalate to the Nodal Officer of the telecom operator.
Contact details of Nodal Officers are published on the telecom operator’s official website.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 30 days, or if unsatisfactory, file a complaint on the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) Portal (https://traicaf.trai.gov.in).
You can also approach the Appellate Authority under TRAI.

documentation_required: Copy of the complaint lodged with the telecom operator
alternative_channels: Telecom operator’s social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to grievance cell
Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: Under TRAI guidelines, telecom operators are required to provide a minimum level of network coverage in rural areas.
You also have the right to approach CPGRAMS (https://pgportal.gov.in) if other channels fail.

issue_type: High Call Drop Rates
issue_description: Frequent disconnections during ongoing calls, resulting in inconvenience and loss of communication.

immediate_action: Contact your telecom operator’s customer care (Toll-Free 1800 series) or visit the nearest store.
Lodge a formal complaint and get a Complaint Reference Number.
Most telecom operators also offer online grievance forms via their websites or mobile apps.
if_unresolved: If not resolved within 3 working days, escalate to the Appellate Authority of the telecom operator.
Contact details of Appellate Authorities are published on the telecom operator’s official website.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 7 days, or if unsatisfactory, file a complaint on the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) Portal (https://www.trai.gov.in).
You can also approach the Consumer Forum under the Consumer Protection Act.

alternative_channels: Telecom operator’s social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to grievance cell
Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: Under TRAI guidelines, telecom operators are required to maintain a certain level of network quality and service standards.
You also have the right to approach the Appellate Authority and TRAI for redressal of grievances.

issue_type: Slow internet speeds
issue_description: The internet speed is slower than the subscribed plan, causing inconvenience in online activities, streaming, and work.

immediate_action: Restart the router and modem to ensure it's not a temporary issue.
Check for any physical obstructions or interference that might be affecting the signal strength.
Contact the internet service provider's (ISP) customer care via phone, email, or live chat.
if_unresolved: If the issue persists, request the ISP to check for any outages or maintenance in your area.
Ask the ISP to perform a speed test to verify the actual speeds you're getting.
Check if there are any issues with your plan or if you need an upgrade.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 3-5 working days, escalate to the ISP's Nodal Officer or Appellate Authority.
File a complaint with the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) or the Department of Telecommunications (DoT).

documentation_required: Date and time of complaint lodging
alternative_channels: ISP's social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to customer care or grievance cell
TRAI's online complaint portal (https://www.trai.gov.in)
Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: Under TRAI guidelines, ISPs must provide speeds of at least 80% of the subscribed speed.
You have the right to approach the Consumer Courts or the Appellate Authority if other channels fail.
ISPs are also required to have a grievance redressal mechanism in place.

issue_description: Incorrect or excessive charges on the telecom bill, including unauthorized services or incorrect data usage calculations.

immediate_action: Contact the telecom operator's customer care (Toll-Free 1800 series) or visit the nearest store.

You can also approach the Consumer Forum for redressal.

issue_type: Inadequate signal strength
issue_description: The signal strength of the telecom network is weak or inconsistent, leading to dropped calls, poor voice quality, or inability to make/receive calls and access data services.

immediate_action: Contact your telecom operator’s customer care (Toll-Free 1800 series) or visit the nearest store/office.
Report the issue and provide your location and phone number for assistance.
Check if the issue is specific to your device or a general network problem in your area.
if_unresolved: If not resolved within 3 working days, request for a complaint reference number and escalate to the Nodal Officer of the telecom operator.
Contact details of Nodal Officers are published on the telecom operator’s official website.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 7 days, or if unsatisfactory, file a complaint on the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) Portal (https://www.trai.gov.in).

alternative_channels: Telecom operator’s social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to customer care
Consumer Helpline 198
important_clauses: Under TRAI guidelines, telecom operators must ensure a minimum signal strength of -80 dBm for 2G and -90 dBm for 3G/4G services.
You also have the right to approach the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, if other channels fail.

issue_type: Difficulty in Porting Numbers
issue_description: The subscriber is facing issues while trying to port their mobile number from one telecom operator to another, which may include delays, rejections, or loss of service during the porting process.

immediate_action: Contact the recipient telecom operator’s customer care to initiate the porting process.
Ensure all required documents are submitted, including a porting form, ID proof, and address proof.
Obtain a Unique Porting Code (UPC) from the current operator.
if_unresolved: If the porting is rejected or delayed, contact the current operator to understand the reason and resolve any pending issues.
Escalate the issue to the Appellate Authority of the telecom operator if the problem persists.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved, file a complaint with the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) through their website or consumer portal.
You can also approach the Telecom Disputes Settlement and Appellate Tribunal (TDSAT) for further redressal.

documentation_required: Porting form duly filled and signed

expected_resolution_time.organization_level: Within 3-4 working days for porting to be completed
expected_resolution_time.regulator_level: 15-30 days after lodging a complaint with TRAI

alternative_channels: Telecom operator’s social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to the customer care or appellate authority
TRAI’s consumer portal or helpline
important_clauses: As per TRAI regulations, the porting process should be completed within 3-4 working days.
Subscribers have the right to port their number without any additional charges, except for a porting fee as specified by TRAI.

issue_type: Poor Wi-Fi connectivity

issue_type: Unregulated use of public spaces

issue_type: Inefficient system for resolving property conflicts
issue_description: The current system for resolving property conflicts is inefficient, leading to delays and frustration for property owners and buyers, often resulting in prolonged legal battles and financial losses.

immediate_action: Contact the local consumer protection council or real estate regulatory authority (e.g., RERA) for guidance and support.
Gather all relevant documents related to the property, including deeds, titles, and contracts.

if_unresolved: If the issue remains unresolved, consider seeking legal counsel to explore options for mediation or litigation.
Engage with local real estate associations or advocacy groups for support and representation.
final_escalation: If all else fails, consider filing a complaint with the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) or approaching the Supreme Court for resolution.
Seek assistance from a consumer rights organization or a public interest litigation firm.

Local consumer protection councils
Online dispute resolution platforms
Social media groups for property owners and buyers
important_clauses: The Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act, 2016, provides for the establishment of real estate regulatory authorities to oversee the sector and resolve disputes.
The Consumer Protection Act, 2019, also applies to real estate transactions, providing additional avenues for redressal.

issue_type: Unregulated use of property for commercial purposes
issue_description: The unauthorized use of residential or other properties for commercial activities without proper licenses and permits, potentially violating zoning laws and disturbing the peace.

immediate_action: Contact local municipal or zoning authorities to report the unregulated commercial use.
Gather evidence such as photos, videos, or witness statements to support your complaint.
Check local ordinances and zoning regulations to understand what is allowed and what is not in your area.
if_unresolved: If the issue persists, file a formal complaint with the local government's planning or zoning department.
Engage with your local community or homeowner's association (if applicable) to raise awareness and build support for addressing the issue.
final_escalation: If the local authorities fail to address the issue, consider filing a lawsuit or seeking legal counsel to explore options for stopping the unregulated commercial activity.
Contact state or national regulatory bodies if the issue involves larger-scale violations or impacts beyond local jurisdiction.

Copies of local zoning laws or ordinances
Witness statements or complaints from neighbors
Complaint reference number from local authorities
Any correspondence with the property owner or operator

expected_resolution_time.organization_level: Within 30 to 60 days, depending on the complexity of the case and the responsiveness of local authorities
expected_resolution_time.regulator_level: Varies, potentially several months to a year or more for legal resolutions

In many jurisdictions, there are specific processes for reporting and addressing zoning violations, which may include fines or other penalties for non-compliance.

issue_type: Inefficient system for tracking property ownership

final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved, consider filing a complaint with the relevant consumer forum or the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission.

issue_type: Unregulated real estate investment schemes

Online dispute resolution platforms, if recognized by the legal system

issue_type: Lack of awareness about electricity conservation

issue_type: High cost of electricity meter testing and calibration

issue_type: Corruption in allocation of electricity contracts

final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after exhausting all other avenues, consider filing a complaint with international organizations, such as the World Bank or the Asian Development Bank, if they are involved in the project.

National Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: The Electricity Act, 2003, mandates that electricity service providers ensure equitable and reliable supply to all consumers, including low-income households.
Low-income households are entitled to subsidies and benefits as per government schemes and policies, such as the Saubhagya scheme or the Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana.

metadata.regulator: State Electricity Regulatory Commission (SERC) or Central Electricity Regulatory Commission (CERC)

issue_type: Poor condition of electrical transmission lines equipment
issue_description: The electrical transmission lines and associated equipment are in a poor condition, leading to frequent power outages, reduced power quality, and potential safety hazards.

immediate_action: Contact the local electricity distribution company’s customer care or visit their office to report the issue.
Provide details of the location and nature of the problem, and request a reference number for the complaint.
Check the company’s website or mobile app for online complaint lodging facilities.
if_unresolved: If not resolved within 15 working days, escalate to the Nodal Officer or the Consumer Grievance Redressal Forum of the distribution company.
Obtain contact details of the Nodal Officer from the company’s website or office.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 30 days, or if unsatisfactory, file a complaint with the State Electricity Regulatory Commission (SERC) or the Electricity Ombudsman.
You can also approach the Consumer Courts for redressal.

documentation_required: Location and description of the poor condition
Photographs or videos of the affected area
Details of previous complaints or interactions with the distribution company
alternative_channels: Distribution company’s social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to customer care or grievance cell
Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: Under the Electricity Act 2003, distribution companies are responsible for maintaining the transmission lines and equipment.

You have the right to approach the CPGRAMS (https://pgportal.gov.in) if other channels fail, and also to claim compensation for any damages or losses incurred due to the poor condition of the transmission lines.

issue_type: Lack of awareness about electrical safety measures
issue_description: The consumer is not aware of the necessary safety precautions and measures to be taken while using electrical appliances, which can lead to accidents and injuries.

immediate_action: Contact the electricity provider’s customer care or visit their website for information on electrical safety.
Download and read the safety guidelines and manuals provided by the electricity provider or appliance manufacturer.
Look for certified safety marks on electrical appliances before purchasing.
if_unresolved: If the issue persists, contact the local electricity distribution company or the state electricity regulatory commission for guidance.
Attend workshops or seminars organized by the electricity provider or regulatory body on electrical safety.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved, file a complaint with the Consumer Grievance Redressal Forum (CGRF) or the Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum.
Approach the National Consumer Helpline (1800-11-4000) for assistance.

documentation_required: Photographs or videos of unsafe electrical conditions
alternative_channels: Electricity provider’s mobile app
Email to customer care
Social media handles (Twitter, Facebook) of the electricity provider
important_clauses: The Electricity Act, 2003, mandates the provision of safe and reliable electricity supply.
The consumer has the right to demand safe and efficient electricity services under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019.

issue_type: High voltage fluctuations in commercial and industrial areas
issue_description: High voltage fluctuations in commercial and industrial areas can cause damage to equipment, disrupt business operations, and pose a risk to safety. This issue requires prompt attention from the electricity provider to prevent further damage and ensure a stable power supply.

immediate_action: Contact the electricity provider’s customer care or visit their website to report the issue.
Provide details of the voltage fluctuations, including the date, time, and location.
Request a reference number or complaint ID for future follow-up.
if_unresolved: If the issue persists, escalate the complaint to the electricity provider’s technical team or a higher authority.
Provide additional information, such as meter readings or equipment damage, to support the complaint.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved, consider filing a complaint with the relevant regulatory body, such as the State Electricity Regulatory Commission (SERC).
Seek assistance from a consumer protection organization or a legal expert if necessary.

documentation_required: Date and time of voltage fluctuations
Details of equipment damage or disruption
alternative_channels: Electricity provider’s mobile app or online portal
Social media handles (Twitter, Facebook)
Email to customer care or technical team
Consumer Grievance Redressal Forum
important_clauses: The Electricity Act, 2003, mandates electricity providers to maintain a stable voltage supply within +/- 5% of the declared voltage.
Consumers have the right to seek compensation for equipment damage or loss due to high voltage fluctuations, as per the provisions of the Consumer Protection Act, 2019.

issue_type: Inadequate power supply for emergency services during natural disasters
issue_description: Inadequate power supply to emergency services such as hospitals, fire stations, and police stations during natural disasters, leading to disruption of critical services.

immediate_action: Contact the local electricity distribution company’s 24-hour helpline or emergency number.
Report the issue to the state electricity regulatory commission’s complaint cell.
Inform the local disaster management authority about the power supply disruption.
if_unresolved: If not resolved within 24 hours, escalate to the state electricity regulatory commission’s appellate authority.
File a complaint with the Consumer Grievance Redressal Forum (CGRF) of the distribution company.
final_escalation: If the issue remains unresolved after 7 days, or if unsatisfactory, approach the National Electricity Regulatory Commission (NERC) or the state electricity ombudsman.
You can also file a petition with the High Court or the Supreme Court under the Electricity Act, 2003.

documentation_required: Date and time of power supply disruption
Supporting documents such as photographs, videos, or witness statements
alternative_channels: Social media handles of the electricity distribution company
Email to the complaint cell of the state electricity regulatory commission
National Consumer Helpline 1800-11-4000
important_clauses: Under the Electricity Act, 2003, it is mandatory for distribution companies to provide uninterrupted power supply to emergency services.
The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) guidelines also emphasize the need for reliable power supply during disasters.

metadata.regulator: Central Electricity Regulatory Commission (CERC) or State Electricity Regulatory Commissions (SERCs)
